Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an infrared scanning near-field optical microscope (IR s-SNOM) for broadband nano-imaging and -spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF) as well as the MPS Office of Multidisciplinary Activities (OMA), Professor Markus Raschke from the University of Colorado Boulder and colleagues Steven Cundiff, Prashant Nagpal, Thomas Perkins, and Sean Shaheen are developing an infrared scanning near-field optical microscope (IR s-SNOM) for broadband nano-imaging and spectroscopy. The instrument provides vibrational and chemical infrared imaging data with nanometer spatial resolution, high spectral resolution and single molecule sensitivity. This instrument is to enable the study of molecular self-organization and nanoscale phase separation in polymer blends, block-copolymers, liquid crystals, and biomembranes; energy and charge transfer in photosynthesis; and organic and inorganic photovoltaics. The award not only allows for the development of a new instrument but also provides training to early career scientists in instrumentation development.

The instrument development effort is being applied to projects such as: (a) studying coupling and transport in organic photovoltaics and electrochemical transistors, (b) achieving label-free access of structure and function of membrane proteins, (c) investigating inter-sub-band transitions in nano-bio-hybrid materials for solar fuel generation, and (d) probing intermolecular coupling and dynamics through local probe vibrational solvatochromism. The technical innovation in IR s-SNOM may lead to new discoveries in soft-matter and quantum materials of utility to imaging technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a new type of ultrahigh spatial resolution infrared microscope for imaging molecular, geochemical, biological, and quantum materials on the nanoscale. Based on the optical antenna properties of a sharp scanning probe microscope tip of a multimodal atomic force microscope, it provides nanometer spatial resolution. In combination with a new bright and broadly tunable ultrashort pulsed laser source, spanning the mid-infrared spectral range, it provides for provides for the first time chemical imaging with nanometer spatial resolution, sub-nm precision, sub-wavenumber spectral resolution, and single molecule sensitivity.

The instrument development effort was driven by a wide range of application needs and it its completed form provides for systematic investigations of the microscopic processes that control complex and multicomponent molecular, geochemical, and biological matter on their elementary level. It is used by collaborators across different departments of the University of Colorado, NIST, and NREL. Examples of specific applications include the study of chemical heterogeneity and polaron formation in perovskite  photovoltaics. Further, it is used for the study of structure, coupling, and dynamics in molecular electronic materials and devices to understand the relationship of local molecular order with the electronic function. In biomaterials it serves to achieve label free access to probing membrane proteins with intrinsic chemical specificity on the single protein level. In geochemistry it is used to probe asphaltene and hydrocarbon-mineral interaction in shale. Other applications include electronic structure and adsorbates in 2D nanomaterials and at interfaces, geo-?microbial systems, and biomineralization.

The instrument provides for collaborative and interdisciplinary research and training in optical nano-imaging and in collaboration with a laser and scanning probe company. All postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates involved in the development project continues their careers in academia or industries related to the project and building on the expertise gained in development this instrument.

The technical innovations the instrument has been based on will lead to new discoveries in molecular soft-matter and quantum materials. The versatile instrument fosters trans?disciplinary collaboration, united by related problems on materials, photonics, biological, and geochemical processes defined on molecular length scales. The project continues to foster true synergies in research, development, education, and training in the emergent frontier of chemical nano-imaging science.
